p: Smoking is a well-established modifying factor in IBD, with opposing effects in CD and UC [ 97], but the mechanism by which it regulates intestinal inflammation is still unclear. The composition of cigarettes is heterogeneous and complex with several chemical elements that may affect different targets in the intestinal cells and modulate the microbiota [ 98, 99]. Other evidence suggests that chemicals released from cigarette smoking can interfere with functions related to the immune response, such as the production of cytokines [ 100], and significantly impact the microbiota [ 101].
